Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: The Economic Benefits of Investing into Social Relationships

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
There has been an exploding interest in the role that social networks play in economic interactions. Developing economies provide an excellent testbed to gain insights about how social networks facilitate economic (see, e.g., Kremer and Miguel (2007), Conley and Udry (2010), Banerjee et al. (2013), Ambrus et al. (2014) for applications to social learning as well as risk-sharing). However, empirical research has been hamstrung by the cost of network data collection. There is a natural tension here. Because networks-based research questions are naturally about interdependence, data from many independent village networks are required for valid statistical analysis. At the same time, a nuanced analysis of social networks requires getting a complete and global picture of the network structure; thus, a survey of the entire community is needed and this can be time-consuming. Researchers typically either have very incomplete network data across many networks or meticulous data across a handful of networks. We propose using a method that reduces the collection of network data tremendously (we estimate 1/6 the cost) so that complete data can be obtained across numerous communities with ease. We apply this to the study of risk-sharing networks. A major factor that limits the extent to which villagers form risk-sharing networks is the fact that parties may not be able to observe each others? incomes (Cole and Kocherlakota (2001)). With increased urbanization and the growth of temporary migration, villagers may be unable to see increasing shares of other households? incomes, which may erode the risk-sharing network. We propose conducting complete network surveys across 100 villages, and then offering an income monitoring service, varying whether or not we reveal income realizations to various community members. We will study (i) the extent to which individuals are better (or worse) able to cope with shocks when they opt for the monitoring service, (ii) how the risk-sharing network evolves in response to our experimental conditions, and (iii) which members of a risk-sharing network are most/least incentivized to migrate.

In this project, we seek to understand how the monitoring function of the social network interacts with the ability to share risk. By randomly revealing information about a temporary migrant?s income to members of the migrant?s home village risk-sharing network, we can cleanly to study how this affects the risk-sharing network. If the information friction is classical, a la Cole and Kocherlakota (2001), committing to reveal the income would increases the scope for insurance. However, if individuals face time-inconsistent temptations to honor requests for transfers from their social networks, predictions are less clear-cut (Banerjee and Mullainathan (2010)). Despite the importance of hidden income, we know very little about how information about incomes actually passes through village social networks. Do individuals feel compelled to hide income information? Does knowledge about income shocks unintentionally diffuse through the network? Thus, the first piece of data we will collect includes a detailed ethnographic survey that will help us understand the perceived incentives to hide/spread income information faced by villagers. The aforementioned network data will be collected using the following protocol. On the first day a team will collect a complete village census, as is typical in many field-based development projects. The key difference is that we will take pictures of the houses as well as any present household members during the census. For a minimal time-cost, we are able to create a facebook of the village. Thus, on the second day, our staff can ask standard networks survey questions used in the literature with the aid of this facebook, which allows us to bypass paper data-entry, minimizes name-matching errors, and saves an immense amount of time relative to using a standard codebook mechanism.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Outcomes Report

We wanted to understand how social networks influence cooperation and risk sharing. In order to achieve this, we worked on two theory papers and designed and ran an economic experiment.

First, we designed an experiment to shed light on issues related to reformulation of groups in relation to investigating free-riding issues in team-settings with the aim of improving co-operative outcomes within a team based on payment interdependencies of team-members as well as the pre-existing social connection between them. The experiment was completed in 6 phases with a total of 420 participants in Karnataka, India. There were 140 teams with 3 members each, which were split in to 2x3 groups, for each group we varied the team composition as well as payment structure. This means in terms of team composition we varied whether team members were friends that signed up together or strangers. In terms of payment structure team members payment was made either based on each individuals output, the entire teams output split equally or in a third case payment was organized through hierarchical incentives. We then analyzed what impact these differential treatments had on productivity, attendance, transfers among group members and perceived efforts of teammates.

We found that among strangers, compared to individual payment the hierarchal payment does not affect attendance, while providing team payment improved attendance outcomes. Conditional on showing up, providing team payment as well as hierarchal payment made productivity worse than in the individual treatment. As far as the transfers are considered, there is no significant difference between individual treatment or either of the group treatments. Finally, among strangers there is no significant difference in rating of partner effort between any of the payment schemes.

For friends, at the individual level attendance was higher as compared to team incentives, while providing hierarchical payments saw improved attendance outcomes as compared to the individual payments. Also, at the individual level, friends attend more when randomly paired with friends than strangers. Conditional on showing up, for friends the productivity was lower under the team incentive payment as compared to the individual payment structure, while there was no significant difference for hierarchal incentives. Transfers are used more by friends in the team payment structure than those provided individual payments and there is some evidence that they are used more by friends in team treatment than by strangers. For all the hierarchy treatments, friends rate the efforts by other teammates lower on average than strangers do, while there are no differences across other payment structures.

In addition to the experiment we also worked on a theoretical paper in which we looked at how risk-sharing within a group is facilitated by individual risk-sharing relationships. Thus, investments into social capital (relationships) provide benefits in terms of facilitating better risk-sharing. We study these investments. First, we show that risk-sharing arrangements that are robust to renegotiation lead the surplus generated by risk-sharing to be allocated disproportionately towards those agents that provide more key risk-sharing links. While this helps generate incentives for agents to invest in such links, our main result uncovers a basic tension between networks that generate equitable outcomes, and those that are stable. Within the class of efficient networks, the most stable network (minimizing the incentives for new links to be formed or existing links deleted) generates the most inequality, while the least stable network generates the least inequality. We show that this basic tension is robust in several dimensions.

Finally, as part of another theoretical paper we looked at contracting limitations on informal risk-sharing contracts that for example can arise from observability, verifiability or complexity constraints. We provide a general characterization of Pareto efficient risk sharing agreements subject to such constraints. We show that, in contrast with predictions of models in which imperfectness of risk-sharing is caused by moral hazard problems, the constraints we investigate induce more centrally located households to take up higher consumption variance. Essentially, these households become quasi insurance providers to more peripheral households.
